Knocking doors (Mantua voters said ours was the first time), engaging in conversations, far & wide, from Mantua (pronounced Man-a-Way) to Magna to Monticello.

We will keep at it. 

We welcome others to join us. https://t.co/MJH0YQSY3w

Some in Utah have told me they call us “Weston Democrats” 

In my view we are simply:

Proud Utah Democrats

Giving Utahns real choices — ideally & increasingly every election — & thereby holding  “entrenched” politicians accountable.
A 50-state national strategy — to bridge dangerous political polarization — should mean a 29-county strategy in our Beehive State. And then putting in the mileage to prove it & do it.
Good candidates should be contesting EVERY race, not only some, and well beyond those perceived as “winnable” or in blue-ish counties or areas. https://t.co/Nv9ryouAxM

Finally:  Josh & Amber said most races in northern Utah go uncontested.

Approximately 40% of races statewide in Utah have only *one* choice this upcoming Election Day. https://t.co/T563MrlXsJ

-no one answered the door at the home with the “Trump 2024 Take America Back” flag. It was the only one we saw in town, though I was told that “Trump caravans” (big trucks with big flags) regularly drive through Brigham City & surrounding areas some weekends. https://t.co/WLbjMIXC5B

-she also said wintertime vehicle parking by snowmobilers was a big problem. 

-another voter expressed concern about “entrenched” politicians who lose contact with the people.

-this voter said she did not understand why Democrats & Republicans “can’t get along.” A neighbor down the road earlier told us, “I’ll never vote for a Dem because of the Dem platform. You can have Romney.” We didn’t quiz him on the Rep platform … what platform? https://t.co/OKRZ8IkTcp
-a retired English & German high school teacher (and yellow tri-cycle rider at age 80+) expressed concern about education: “phones should not be allowed in the classroom.” https://t.co/ut1Tw1F3HD

-a young power line repairman (Nephi, UT, native) said this was the second election he could vote in — the last one he hadn’t, adding "I will focus on the person, not the party."

The alfalfa industry “is not only one of the largest water users in the basin, but one of the most powerful. Farmers have faced growing criticism for…growing a thirsty crop – none of which goes directly to feeding people – in a drought-stricken region.”https://t.co/VIZIfqCt7p

This is a memorable & spot-on quote from a wise Utah teenager: 

“Her 17-year old son Moses hopes other adults will follow his parents’ example. ‘Grass is stupid,’ he says. ‘We live in a desert.’”

“They point to the success of southern Nevada, which decreased its water use over a period of 12 years by 32bn gallons even as it accommodated half a million new residents, primarily by paying people to rip out their lawns.”
“Environmentalists argue there is easily enough water to meet Utah’s future needs if people would just stop wasting it on ornamental turf.”

“Utah’s population is predicted to grow to 5.5 million people by 2050. Water companies and some state politicians insist various multibillion-dollar development projects are required to meet future demand.”

“The pricing structure also seems to encourage Utahns, regardless of income, to use a lot of water – 178 gallons a person a day, nearly double the national average. And it gives tax exempt entities such as the Mormon church a huge price break.”

To repair …

To rebuild …

This particular candidate (aka “Kael al-Falluji”) has been tested before in a big way. I remain committed to bringing people together because that is what I know how to do. What I learned to do in the most extreme circumstances. #ExperienceMatters

https://t.co/PJkEvk2w5x

Today’s challenges at home are not more challenging than those the U.S. military and I faced in distant lands, scattered with bombs. 

But the stakes are similarly high.

I am ready to represent Utah’s 2nd Congressional District in Washington because of my seven years of experience in two war zones. Despite all the challenges, we were able to find solutions & work toward common ground—ground that had too much American, Iraqi, & Afghan blood on it. https://t.co/Yy4wpNYano
Those days were hard, but these days hit home—because it is our own country that I am trying to help repair, not one half-way around the world in a war that I opposed. https://t.co/lKA53WJYpC

Today, COVID has killed over 175,000 Americans. As our nation’s political dysfunction worsens and red-blue divisions only seem to be getting deeper, I often think back to my time in the wars. https://t.co/k4hbUpPhGn

By my third year in the city, Fallujah’s leaders said that I could only leave “after Fallujah is happy again.”
I had a hard time imagining when that would ever happen, but I stayed. https://t.co/zFcwqCHPwN

My State Department job was to be a literal human bridge between U.S. Marines and Iraqis. So much so that Fallujans once told my boss, the ambassador, that I was known in the city as “Kael al-Falluji.” #BridgingDivides

Fallujah proved to be a multi-layered challenge that taught me a lot about the importance of building relationships by listening first -- persistently -- particularly with those who might disagree & come from very different backgrounds. #EmpathyMatters https://t.co/HfalRy3RVG
Tragically, civilians were caught in the cross-fire, too. Both Marine and Iraqi friends of mine, dozens, were killed and wounded in those red years. https://t.co/3iXOUyqMkF

In Iraq’s dangerous “city of mosques,” I was charged with establishing local governance in a violent place that was half-leveled by Marine firepower in late 2004, in an attempt to rid the city of terrorists. https://t.co/ZiqRlOMbI8

Since announcing my run last Dec, I've listened a lot. That's how we cultivate relations across a district that includes 14 counties. 

Not that much different from the skills I honed in two warzones, particularly in Fallujah during & after the biggest battle of the Iraq War. https://t.co/riomvZWqki

When done well, it requires repeat visits—not a drive-by, or election year-only, approach to constituent outreach.

That is why I am back on the road this week. More miles. More vistas. More voices. #CD2 #Utah https://t.co/e6GalRLYlX
